beer.title: Beer
beer.description: A fermented beverage made from grain mash, typically barley
basicSteps: Malting - Soak and germinate barley to activate enzymes
Mashing - Heat crushed grains in water (144-158°F) to convert starches to sugars
Boiling - Add hops and boil wort for 60-90 minutes
Fermentation - Cool wort and pitch yeast (65-75°F for ales)
Bottling - Package beer with priming sugar for carbonation

malting.title: Malting Process
malting.description: Barley is steeped in water for 40-48 hours, then spread out to germinate for 4-5 days at controlled temperature and humidity. During germination, enzymes are activated that will later convert starches to fermentable sugars. The grain is then kiln-dried to halt germination and develop color and flavor.

mashing.title: Mashing Process
mashing.description: Crushed malted grains are mixed with hot water in a temperature-controlled environment. Different temperature rests activate specific enzymes: beta-amylase (140-149°F) for highly fermentable wort, alpha-amylase (154-162°F) for more body and residual sweetness.

boiling.title: Wort Boiling
boiling.description: The sweet liquid (wort) is boiled vigorously for 60-90 minutes. Hops are added at different times: bittering hops at the start, flavor hops in the middle, and aroma hops near the end. The boil sterilizes the wort, concentrates sugars, and isomerizes hop compounds.

fermentation.title: Fermentation
fermentation.description: Cooled wort is transferred to a fermenter and yeast is added. Ale yeasts work best at 65-75°F, while lager yeasts prefer 45-55°F. Primary fermentation takes 3-7 days, followed by conditioning period. The yeast converts sugars to alcohol and CO2 while producing flavor compounds.

bottling.title: Bottling Process
bottling.description: Beer is packaged with precise amounts of priming sugar to achieve desired carbonation levels. Bottles are filled with minimal oxygen exposure and capped securely. The residual yeast ferments the priming sugar to naturally carbonate the beer over 1-2 weeks.

maltedBarley.title: Malted Barley
maltedBarley.description: The foundation of beer, malted barley provides fermentable sugars and enzymes necessary for brewing. Different roast levels create various colors and flavors, from light pilsner malt to dark roasted barley.

hops.title: Hops
hops.description: Flowers of the hop plant that provide bitterness, flavor, and aroma to beer. Also act as a natural preservative. Different varieties offer unique characteristics from floral to citrus to pine.

yeast.title: Brewing Yeast
yeast.description: Microorganisms that convert sugars into alcohol and CO2. Two main types: ale yeast (top-fermenting) and lager yeast (bottom-fermenting), each producing distinct flavor profiles.

water.title: Filtered Water
water.description: The main component of beer, water's mineral content significantly impacts flavor and brewing efficiency. Different beer styles traditionally developed around local water profiles.

brandy.title: Brandy
brandy.description: A spirit produced by distilling wine or fermented fruit juice
basicSteps: Base Preparation - Select and prepare wine

basePreparation.title: Base Wine Selection
basePreparation.description: Quality wine is selected for distillation. For fruit brandies, fresh fruit is crushed and fermented. The base wine significantly impacts final character. Proper acid and sugar balance is crucial.

distillation.title: Brandy Distillation
distillation.description: First distillation concentrates alcohol to about 30%. Second distillation in copper pot stills reaches 65-70%. Careful cuts separate heads, hearts, and tails. Temperature control is crucial for flavor development.

aging.title: Oak Aging
aging.description: New spirit ages in oak barrels, often Limousin or American oak. Aging develops color, smoothness, and complexity. Duration varies from 2 years to decades. Regular monitoring ensures proper development.

blending.title: Master Blending
blending.description: Different aged brandies are blended to achieve desired character. Master blenders maintain house style consistency. Age statements reflect youngest brandy in blend.

wine.title: Base Wine
wine.description: High-quality wine forms the foundation of brandy. The wine's characteristics directly influence the final spirit's flavor profile. Traditional grape varieties include Ugni Blanc, Colombard, and Folle Blanche.

yeast.title: Wine Yeast
yeast.description: Specialized strains of Saccharomyces cerevisiae convert fruit sugars to alcohol during the initial fermentation phase. Different strains produce varying flavor compounds.

oak.title: Oak Barrels
oak.description: Essential for aging brandy, oak barrels contribute vanilla, spice, and tannin compounds while allowing controlled oxidation. Different oak species and toast levels affect flavor development.

water.title: Pure Water
water.description: Used to adjust the final proof of the brandy. Water quality and mineral content can affect the spirit's mouthfeel and flavor integration.

cider.title: Cider
cider.description: A fermented alcoholic beverage made from apple juice
basicSteps: Packaging - Bottle or keg final product

fruitSelection.title: Apple Selection
fruitSelection.description: Specific apple varieties are chosen for sugar content, acidity, and tannins. Blend of varieties creates complexity. Apples must be ripe and free from rot. Traditional cider apples are preferred.

pressing.title: Juice Extraction
pressing.description: Apples are washed, ground into pomace, then pressed. Clean equipment prevents contamination. Juice is tested for sugar content and acidity. Pectic enzyme may be added to improve extraction and clarity.

fermentation.title: Cider Fermentation
fermentation.description: Juice ferments at 60-65°F. Wild yeast or cultured strains convert sugars to alcohol. Fermentation takes 1-2 weeks. Temperature control affects flavor development. Nutrients may be added if needed.

aging.title: Maturation
aging.description: Cider ages for clarity and flavor development. Duration varies from weeks to months. Some producers age in oak. Regular tasting monitors progress. Racking removes sediment.

apples.title: Fresh Apple Juice
apples.description: Made from specific apple varieties bred for cider making, containing ideal balance of sugars, tannins, and acids. Traditional varieties include Kingston Black, Dabinett, and Yarlington Mill.

yeast.title: Cider Yeast
yeast.description: Specialized strains that thrive in apple juice conditions, producing clean fermentation and enhancing fruit character. Can be wild or cultured strains.

enzyme.title: Pectic Enzyme
enzyme.description: Breaks down pectin in apple juice, improving juice extraction and final clarity. Essential for commercial production and clear ciders.

sulfites.title: Sulfites
sulfites.description: Preservative that inhibits wild yeast and bacteria, protecting cider from spoilage. Also acts as an antioxidant during aging.

gin.title: Gin
gin.description: A spirit flavored with juniper berries and other botanicals
basicSteps: Base Spirit - Create or source neutral spirit
Botanical Prep - Select and prepare botanicals

baseSpirit.title: Base Spirit Production
baseSpirit.description: High-quality neutral spirit is produced or sourced. Must be clean and pure as it carries botanical flavors. Typically grain-based, distilled to 96% ABV.

botanicalPrep.title: Botanical Preparation
botanicalPrep.description: Juniper berries and other botanicals are carefully selected and prepared. Some are crushed to release oils, others left whole. Proportions are crucial for balanced flavor.

distillation.title: Gin Distillation
distillation.description: Spirit is redistilled with botanicals. Vapor infusion uses botanical baskets above spirit. Cuts are made to capture desired flavors. Each distillery has unique methods.

spirit.title: Neutral Grain Spirit
spirit.description: High-proof base alcohol distilled to near neutrality, providing clean canvas for botanical flavors. Usually made from wheat, corn, or other grains.

juniper.title: Juniper Berries
juniper.description: The defining botanical of gin, providing distinctive pine and resinous notes. Must be the predominant flavor by law in most countries.

coriander.title: Coriander Seeds
coriander.description: Second most common gin botanical, adding citrus and nutty notes. Works synergistically with juniper to create classic gin profile.

botanicals.title: Various Botanicals
botanicals.description: Blend of roots, herbs, spices, and peels that create gin's complex flavor profile. Common ingredients include angelica root, orris root, citrus peel, and cardamom.

mead.title: Mead
mead.description: An ancient alcoholic beverage made from fermented honey
basicSteps: Must Preparation - Mix honey and water

mustPreparation.title: Must Creation
mustPreparation.description: Honey is mixed with water to achieve desired gravity. Temperature control prevents damage to honey compounds. Some producers heat must, others use raw process. Nutrients added to support fermentation.

fermentation.title: Mead Fermentation
fermentation.description: Specialized yeast converts honey sugars to alcohol. Temperature maintained at 65-75°F. Primary fermentation takes 2-4 weeks. Nutrients added in stages. Gravity monitored regularly.

aging.title: Aging Process
aging.description: Mead ages to develop complexity. Duration varies from months to years. Temperature control prevents oxidation. Some producers age in oak. Regular tasting tracks development.

honey.title: Raw Honey
honey.description: The primary fermentable sugar source for mead. Different honey varieties (wildflower, orange blossom, buckwheat) create distinct flavor profiles and characteristics.

yeast.title: Mead Yeast
yeast.description: Specialized strains capable of fermenting high-sugar environments. Selected for alcohol tolerance and ability to preserve honey character.

water.title: Pure Water
water.description: Used to dilute honey to proper fermentation density. Water chemistry affects fermentation and final flavor profile.

nutrients.title: Yeast Nutrients
nutrients.description: Essential additions providing nitrogen and minerals needed for healthy fermentation, as honey lacks natural yeast nutrients.

rum.title: Rum
rum.description: A spirit made from sugarcane byproducts

materialPrep.title: Raw Material Processing
materialPrep.description: Molasses or fresh cane juice prepared for fermentation. Brix and pH adjusted. For agricole rum, cane juice must be processed quickly. Water quality impacts fermentation.

fermentation.title: Rum Fermentation
fermentation.description: Unique yeast strains create rum's distinctive profile. Dunder may be added for complexity. Temperature control affects ester formation. Fermentation takes 24-72 hours.

distillation.title: Rum Distillation
distillation.description: Pot still or column still distillation. Each method produces different style. Cuts carefully made to capture desired flavors. Multiple distillations may be used.

aging.title: Barrel Aging
aging.description: Aging in oak develops color and flavor. Tropical climate accelerates aging. Different barrel types impact character. Some producers use solera system.

molasses.title: Molasses/Sugarcane
molasses.description: The primary source of fermentable sugars in rum. Molasses provides rich, complex flavors while fresh cane juice (used in rhum agricole) offers grassy, vegetal notes.

yeast.title: Rum Yeast
yeast.description: Specialized strains that produce desired ester profiles and flavor compounds. Many distilleries maintain proprietary cultures passed down through generations.

dunder.title: Dunder
dunder.description: Residue from previous fermentations, adds complexity and traditional Jamaican rum character. Rich in compounds that promote ester formation.

water.title: Water
water.description: Used throughout production for dilution and proof adjustment. Many historic rum distilleries were established near pristine water sources.

sake.title: Sake
sake.description: A Japanese rice wine made through multiple parallel fermentation
basicSteps: Rice Polishing - Mill rice to specific ratio
Koji Making - Cultivate koji on rice

ricePolishing.title: Rice Preparation
ricePolishing.description: Rice is polished to remove outer layers. Polishing ratio determines sake grade. Higher grades remove more outer portion. Rice is then washed and soaked precisely.

kojiMaking.title: Koji Cultivation
kojiMaking.description: Steamed rice is inoculated with koji mold. Process takes 48 hours in koji room. Temperature and humidity carefully controlled. Koji converts rice starch to sugar.

moromi.title: Main Fermentation
moromi.description: Three-stage process adds rice, koji, and water to starter. Multiple parallel fermentation occurs. Temperature kept low for clean flavor. Takes 18-32 days.

rice.title: Sake Rice
rice.description: Special varieties grown specifically for sake brewing, with larger, starch-rich centers. The degree of polishing affects the final grade and character.

koji.title: Koji Mold
koji.description: Aspergillus oryzae, essential for converting rice starch into fermentable sugars. Creates unique parallel fermentation process distinctive to sake.

yeast.title: Sake Yeast
yeast.description: Specialized strains that produce desired flavor compounds and can ferment to high alcohol levels while maintaining delicate aromatics.

water.title: Soft Water
water.description: Specific mineral content crucial for sake brewing. Historic brewing regions were established around renowned water sources.

tequila.title: Tequila
tequila.description: A Mexican spirit made from blue agave

harvesting.title: Agave Harvesting
harvesting.description: Blue Weber Agave harvested at 7-10 years. Jimadors select mature plants. Piñas (hearts) trimmed of leaves. Sugar content tested before processing.

cooking.title: Agave Cooking
cooking.description: Piñas steam-cooked in traditional ovens or autoclaves. Process converts complex carbohydrates to simple sugars. Cooking develops characteristic flavors. Takes 24-48 hours.

distillation.title: Double Distillation
distillation.description: First distillation creates ordinario. Second distillation concentrates and purifies. Copper pot stills traditional. Cuts made to capture heart of distillation.

agave.title: Blue Weber Agave
agave.description: The heart (piña) of the blue agave plant, harvested after 7-10 years of growth. Must be grown in designated regions of Mexico for tequila designation.

yeast.title: Tequila Yeast
yeast.description: Strains selected for their ability to produce desired flavor compounds during fermentation of agave sugars. Can be proprietary or traditional strains.

water.title: Spring Water
water.description: Natural spring water used throughout production process. Mineral content affects fermentation and final character of the spirit.

vodka.title: Vodka
vodka.description: A clear spirit made from fermented grains or potatoes
ingredients: Base material (wheat, rye, corn, potato, or other)

preparation.title: Raw Material Processing
preparation.description: Base ingredients are cleaned and processed. Potatoes are cooked to gelatinize starches, grains are milled and cooked. Quality of raw materials significantly impacts final product.

distillation.title: Multiple Distillation
distillation.description: Wash undergoes multiple distillations in column stills. Each pass increases purity and alcohol content. Precise cuts remove unwanted compounds. Modern stills may have 20+ plates.

filtration.title: Charcoal Filtration
filtration.description: Spirit is filtered through activated carbon to remove remaining impurities. Multiple filtrations may be used. Water is added to achieve final proof. Temperature during filtration affects final character.

base.title: Base Materials
base.description: Various agricultural products can be used: wheat, rye, corn, potato, or other starch-rich materials. Each imparts subtle character to final spirit.

enzymes.title: Enzymes
enzymes.description: Convert complex starches into fermentable sugars. Can be naturally present in malted grains or added as commercial preparations.

yeast.title: Distiller's Yeast
yeast.description: Clean-fermenting strains selected for neutral flavor production and high alcohol tolerance. Critical for producing pure base spirit.

carbon.title: Activated Carbon
carbon.description: Used in filtration to remove congeners and achieve characteristic neutrality. Different types of carbon affect filtering efficiency.

whiskey.title: Whiskey
whiskey.description: A spirit made from fermented grain mash
ingredients: Base grains (malted barley, corn, rye, or wheat)
basicSteps: Mashing - Convert starches to fermentable sugars

malting.title: Grain Malting
malting.description: Barley is soaked and allowed to germinate, developing enzymes needed for starch conversion. For peated whiskey, malted barley is dried over peat smoke. Temperature and moisture are carefully controlled throughout the process.

mashing.title: Whiskey Mashing
mashing.description: Ground grains are mixed with hot water in a mash tun. Temperature rests activate enzymes that convert starches to fermentable sugars. The resulting sweet liquid (wort) is cooled and prepared for fermentation.

distillation.title: Whiskey Distillation
distillation.description: The wash is distilled twice (or thrice) in copper pot stills. The first distillation (wash still) creates low wines. The second (spirit still) produces new make spirit. Careful cuts separate desired heart from heads and tails.

aging.title: Barrel Aging
aging.description: New make spirit ages in oak barrels, often for years. The wood imparts color and flavor while allowing slow oxidation. Temperature fluctuations drive spirit in and out of wood, extracting compounds. Legal minimum aging varies by type.

grains.title: Base Grains
grains.description: Different grains create distinct whiskey styles: barley for Scotch, corn for bourbon, rye for rye whiskey. Malted barley provides essential enzymes for conversion.

yeast.title: Distiller's Yeast
yeast.description: Proprietary strains that produce desired flavor compounds during fermentation. Each distillery maintains unique cultures contributing to house character.

water.title: Water
water.description: Used throughout production from mashing to final dilution. Many historic distilleries were built near distinctive water sources.

peat.title: Peat
peat.description: Decomposed vegetation used to smoke malted barley in some Scotch whiskies. Imparts distinctive smoky, earthy flavors to final spirit.

wine.title: Wine
wine.description: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented grape juice
basicSteps: Harvesting - Pick grapes at optimal ripeness
Crushing - Process grapes to release juice
Fermentation - Convert grape sugars to alcohol
Pressing - Separate wine from grape solids

harvesting.title: Grape Harvesting
harvesting.description: Grapes are harvested when they reach optimal sugar content (Brix), acidity, and phenolic ripeness. Timing is crucial - typically pre-dawn to preserve freshness. Hand-harvesting allows for selective picking, while machine harvesting is more efficient for larger operations.

crushing.title: Grape Crushing
crushing.description: Grapes are destemmed and crushed to release juice. For white wines, grapes are pressed immediately. For reds, the juice ferments with skins and seeds for color and tannin extraction. Modern crushers are gentle to avoid bitter compounds from seeds.

fermentation.title: Wine Fermentation
fermentation.description: Fermentation occurs at controlled temperatures: whites at 55-65°F, reds at 70-85°F. Wild yeast or cultured strains convert grape sugars to alcohol over 5-14 days. Red wines undergo malolactic fermentation for smoothness. Temperature control is crucial for flavor development.

aging.title: Wine Aging
aging.description: Wines age in tanks, barrels, or bottles. Oak barrels impart flavors and allow micro-oxygenation. Duration varies by style: whites typically 6-12 months, reds 1-2 years or more. Temperature and humidity control are essential for proper aging.

grapes.title: Wine Grapes
grapes.description: Specific varieties of Vitis vinifera cultivated for winemaking. Different varieties offer unique flavor profiles, tannin levels, and acidity.

yeast.title: Wine Yeast
yeast.description: Saccharomyces cerevisiae strains selected for wine production. Can be native from grape skins or cultured strains chosen for specific characteristics.

sulfites.title: Sulfites
sulfites.description: Preservative compounds that protect wine from oxidation and microbial spoilage. Also help preserve color and freshness during aging.

fining.title: Fining Agents
fining.description: Materials used to clarify wine by removing suspended particles. Traditional agents include egg whites, isinglass, and bentonite clay.
